text: Easily the best game I played last year, with hollow knight in a close second. I went into the game not expecting an emotional and genuine story, and the music by Lena Raine perfectly complements the themes in the game. The soundtrack as a whole is outstanding, but "Quiet and Falling" has always been my favorite track.

text: This artwork looks like some kinda Celeste/MHA crossover. Anyway, this is a really cool and atmospheric song from a soundtrack filled with lots of amazing tracks just like it. Though I like the sound of the B-Side remix better, the original does a great job of making some simple non-linear exploration suddenly feel much more tense and uncertain. Love hearing the synth choir hitting those high notes in spots like 3:00 and 3:38.

text: I'm still incredibly surprised at how much attention this game got. Perfect reviews, game of the year nominations, etc. and those NEVER happen for a 2D pixel indie game. I haven't played it yet, so I'm really curious as to what makes it THAT good.
author: Hawlo

text:
To me, what makes Celeste a great game is the sum of its parts. It's open to both casual and hardcore gamers, has good gameplay/controls, good music, good art/animation, and a good story---it's overall a very polished game that hits a wide audience. Most people can play the game and come away with something they enjoy about it. 


Bonus points for me:
1) Story about depression is not a PSA, but has some realism to it
2) Strong female protagonist
3) I reaaally like the art/animations
author: SadFace

text:
-It just might be a perfect game in terms of designing difficulty accessibility for ALL players.  I can't think of another game that seamlessly supports the most casual with assist mode to the most hardcore with B and C sides.  Even 90% of strawberries are on completely optional screens just for those that want more challenge.
-The way the story seems to tie into the gameplay mechanics in deep ways is pretty awesome.
-The gameplay is so tight on certain mechanics that really could've been hard to pull off like the green/red orbs, and the "dream" blocks (most fun ever!!).

author: Omnipotat0

text: When I first played Celeste, I didn’t expect its story to resonate with me the way it did. Madeline might just be one of the most relatable protagonists I’ve ever played and the game’s music gives you a better glimpse into her thoughts and feelings than any amount of dialogue. Celeste is a magnificent platformer and I’m glad that it sold well enough for the developer to continue the story with Chapter 9.

text: So beautiful and yet, so lonely
author: Karlos Katu

text: I'll start by saying I've never been the biggest "challenging 2D platformers" fan like Super Meat Boy for example, but there is something about Celeste that makes it easily my favorite in that genre. It's the sum of its parts, but also the way it feels difficult without being unfair. A checkpoint at the start of each room, quick retries when you die, gameplay that gives you perfect control of Madeline and amazing level design that flows very well to create memorable stages. I do wish the levels felt a bit more naturally organic in terms of geometry since it is very easy to see it was made using square tiles. The meaningful story about Madeline dealing with her depression/anxiety was also a central part of the game and I know it resonated with a lot of people. It's made even more thought provoking when you learn that the developer himself had to face that battle during the game's development and decided to give what was to be simply a challenging platformer such a metaphor. The soundtrack by Lena Raine is also top notch and contributed in making the Mirror Temple what is probably my favorite game level in 2018, the piano kicking in at 2:33 hits all the right notes.
author: SupraDarky

text: @TalesOfGod # Celeste is amazing, highly recommend it
author: AzerFraze

text: As someone who really loves tight, challenging platformers, I think simple geometry is a necessity.  It's the simple, well-defined behaviors that make gameplay feel tight in the first place.  Physics-based platformers absolutely never achieve that feeling.
author: totlyepic

text: @totlyepic That's a very fair point, but I do believe it is feasible to keep the simple geometry while visually hiding it organically. Of course, it has to be done in a way that doesn't impair the behavior which is why it's such a challenge to do in the first place. Games that do it well mostly use parts of the platforms (like the underside) that are not directly involved in player traversal, as well as the floors and ceilings.
author: SupraDarky

text: The game's developer had some old GameMaker titles - the 'Jumper' series, from whence came the 'Ogmo' skin for Super Meat Boy - and that showcased their skill in crafting these tight platformers.  When I played Celeste, I realized almost immediately this was the same fellow.  Some familiar mechanics, and the specific feel of it was just familiar.  They're excellent at their craft, and I'm glad they're finally able to make money for their work.
author: Fellshard

text: @SupraDarky Hollow Knight is probably the best game at hiding its use of square tiles. I didn't notice that there weren't slopes in the entire game until like my third playthrough.
author: Welcome to Valhalla

text: @SupraDarky ​ Welcome to Valhalla  I agree that Hollow Knight is actually probably the best example.  I was super worried before playing it that scenes would be too noisy/not readable, but that proved to be untrue.  They do a good job of using blurring/focus and subtle animations to make it clear what's just dressing and what's functional.
author: totlyepic
